Comment: SAA have had numerous CEO's and acting CEO's over the last decade and each one comes up with a new "turnaround strategy" which inevitably fails.
Their ratio of staff to aircraft operated (a simple measure of productivity) is way higher than international norms and best practice - at OR Tambo, sometimes there are more people hanging around or chatting in groups in blue SAA uniforms than there are passengers, and half of those passengers work for government or parastatals, anyway (travelling business class often).

One of the reasons that Standard Chartered bank refused to roll over or extend the loans is that they own some of the aircraft that SAA operate. As PG said, "join the dots".

Best solution is privatisation, but that will not happen under Gigaba(ge).
SAA is technically insolvent, so there is no equity anyway - no-one buys liabilities without more assets to cover them.

Second best solution is bankruptcy - take the 20 billion plus hit, but at least the blood then stops flowing.

Comment: Okay, I dislike Trump as much as the next sane person, but this story is getting over sensationalized and is flat out inaccurate. Trump actually has nothing to do with this - it was a decision made by NOAA, for which Trump has yet to hire a director. This decision was based on a cost-benefit analysis by NOAA of the effectiveness of existing protections (quite good) versus the perceived economic strain to fisheries were the additional protection mandated. Efforts to reduce whale and turtle bycatch has reduced associated deaths of these creatures to about 1 each per year, and the protection would mandate that a fishery must close for a certain amount of time if 2 or more were caught. 

This is the second article I've seen like this on this issue and now I'm starting to see why so many are frustrated with the media lately.

Comment: WTH did people think was going to reduce all the various forms of pollution, and its consequences?
Did they think the Pollution Fairy was going to drop by one night and make it all go away?

For generations we have lived like spoiled brats on this planet--& we continue to do so.
We buy useless & wasteful & unnecessary things that even our parents',& certainly our grandparents' generations, would be horror-stricken by. How many vehicles? 'Entertainment centres'? See-doos? Leaf-blowers? Disposable diapers? Plastic bags?

How many tons of natural resources do those things consumer? Wood, precious metals, energy to obtain them, manufacture them, ship them, advertise them, sell them, dispose of them?

For decades we have known that there is no place on the planet that has entirely clean air, clean water, or clean soil.
And we have given not one single damn, for our children or their children. The latest toy or outfit has been more important.

Suck it up buttercup--the bill is long past due.

Comment: @retired juggie, I tend to agree with you for the most part and was merely using LB and WM as examples of corporate failures in similar businesses. I'll just defend my other post by saying Lehman may not have been a mortgage originator but it collapsed as a direct result of investing in mortgage debt instruments as did Bear Stearns. WaMu suffered a run on the bank due to it's shaky mortgage business. There are direct parallels to our Big 5, residential mortgages passed the $1 Trillion mark in Canada last year and make up the single largest portion of all the banks' businesses. The difference here however, is that CMHC backstops high-ratio mortgages and OSFI regulation essentially keeps the Schedule 1 banks out of the sub-prime market making credit risk considerably lower than the US experience.

Comment: I agree that marriage is like communion--it's also a bond of attachment, and the capacity for a secure attachment first develops in infancy, but not always.  
There are spiritual aspects as well that aren't fully understood.  
 The wedding is the beginning but the relationship is a living thing that must be renewed. Sometimes the relationship dies and the hierarchy needs to recognize that.  But that death is a long process--it can be that the two spouses have grown emotionally in different directions, or that one has grown and the other has not; it can be due to a lack of communication skills where when differences arise and they fight, they don't know how to reconcile or other.  Each marriage is different just as each individual is different.  If Catholic priests were married they would have experienced this themselves and would understand it.  I know a number of couples who have been married for over 40 years, some up to 70 years.  How do they do it?  The Church should find out.

Comment: My experience is that protest organized inside a political party is far more effective (and far more consistent with our Parliamentary democracy to boot).

For example, NDP Leader Ed Broadbent shamed the government into reforming insurance company and banking taxation when he repeated, day after day, that the teller at a Canadian bank paid more income tax than the bank did.

I could also cite David Lewis' slogan of "corporate welfare bums" as producing reforms.

For that matter, the "ringing of the (division) bells" by Joe Clark's PCs forced Pierre Trudeau to make amendments to the Charter of Rights. 

I was able to secure many important changes for my constituents in the House (such as lowering credit card interest rates and banking fees) using their real life examples.

However satisfying raucous street protests are; the record indicates political action produces far larger, and more important, results.

Comment: There is a simple experiment you can do at home, to see just how pro-immigration this Canadian newspaper is, the Globe and Mail.

You get a hint of it in this article, right here: "Australia has seen the rise of nationalist, anti-immigration politics".

Anti-immigration? What a curious and striking phrase.

Well, here' the experiment. Go up to the "news search" window and type in that phrase, "anti-immigration".

The result: Close to a THOUSAND articles have recently used the phrase.

Now go up and type a search for the phrase "pro-immigration".

The result? A few dozen articles.

Wow. This newspaper thrusts forward the phrase "anti-immigration" about twenty times as often as the phrase "pro-immigration".

You see how that works, right, if you are running the newspaper? The fact that you almost never identify a pro-immigration politician or a pro-immigration political party is because you want to NORMALIZE that as simply NORMAL, nothing to see here, folks, move along.

It's Orwellian.

Comment: [The Electoral College is decided upon by the CONSTITUTIONAL popular election in individual states.]
Could you please cite the passage in the Constitution that involves popular election of the president?  Because the Constitution provides in Article 2, Section 1:
"Each state shall appoint, in such manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a number of electors, equal to the whole number of Senators and Representatives to which the State may be entitled in the Congress"
The electoral college does not function upon popular elections under the Constitution.  Each sate could decide to have an elector vote based upon a coin flip for all the Constitution provides so I don't see how you can claim that.  The fact that states actually chose to determine which elector will vote based upon popular election in incidental to the Constitution.

Eventually she was called to the Dean of Women's office, and according to my friend, was told she had to stop being seen with this black student-athlete or she would be stripped of all her campus offices.  That's the way  the UO enforced institutional  racism in those days.
Phi Delta Theta had an adviser at the UO who was also our adviser at our PDT chapter at Willamette-- he came and told us if we pledged a n----- we'd immediately lose our charter.
So this is how it was in the past  and thank God  now we're  climbing out of the racist muck.

Comment: So the proposal is to make tourists pay for a rail system that will not service Waikiki.  Can't see that going over too well with most of our visitors.  And while they don't vote here, their reactions will influence others who are thinking about coming to Hawaii, especially in this age of social media.

A better option would be to raise the TAT to cover the cost of extending the line from Ala Moana to Waikiki, and keep the increase in place thereafter to help defray operating expenses since tourists would be using the expanded system.  That would allow the GET surcharge to be discontinued after the current project is paid for, rather than extended indefinitely to pay for operations.

Comment: Just like clockwork someone will defend the current (lack of) rules by stating that we have a citizen legislature in a small population so conflicts are unavoidable. OK...so let's look at Wyoming, a state with a much smaller population than ours at 538,000. Here's their conflict of interest rule: "A member who has a personal or private interest in any measure or bill proposed or pending before the legislature shall disclose the fact to the house of which he is a member, and shall not vote thereon.”
Get that?  If they have a conflict, they don't vote. Period. If Wyoming can make that rule work, we should demand no less.

Comment: Well, well David ... Exactly what might I learn from Nicollelo? 

I did learn that she thinks the Eugene adopted street standards "prove" that a 14-foot wide, potentially obstructed pavement is "safe" for emergency response vehicles. She's dead wrong on the law, which she would have learned from even the slightest paying attention to the language and City Council's legally-adopted findings. She's also dead wrong on what the Eugene Fire Code requires for a safe "fire apparatus access road." She's also dead wrong on the practical aspects because two fire trucks or an ambulance and a fire truck cannot pass one another on such a substandard road.
 
I prefer to be called "Mr. Know-enough." And I believe I know-enough to think that Rick Duncan wouldn't have botched this decision that will endanger people's lives.

The ink is long dry Nicollelo's bad judgment.

-- Paul

Comment: If you actually want an answer to why your premium jumped so precipitously you'd have to talk to both the Chief Actuary and the Chief Underwriting Officer of the company.

I can think of a number of reasons - the obvious one is the company decided that their premiums were far too low to start with so the imposed an across the board increase (which may have affected some classes differently than others).  They may simply have decided that they were losing their shirts in a particular territory or for a particular class of drivers and decided they really didn't want to insure that group any more - the obvious solution - increase premiums for those drivers to the point that they go to another company.  As an observation, if it was the latter your insurance broker is at fault - he should have taken the hint and shopped your policy to find you cheaper coverage elsewhere.

Comment: There are different standards relating to personal free speech rights and commercial rights.   Advertising for commercial activities is not protected in the same manner or extent as personal or individual free speech.  The courts have ruled time and time again that commercial speech is subject to regulation and restrictions.

So the City attorneys better put on their thinking caps and earn their high price salaries to put these sidewalk hawkers off our sidewalks where they pose a danger to those of us who have to dodge their carts and wagons.  If the city would use a lick of common sense all these people would be off the sidewalks if a simple test was run.  The test would be to see what happens when a car veers off the street, an air raid siren goes off, or a fire breaks out in a store.  In those circumstances, the sidewalks are meant to provide a safe way to escape, not to be obstructed by hawkers or "religious" nuts.  Safety first, even before free speech.

Comment: Eliane, I may be wrong, but it seems to me that Cardinal Bernardin was not saying that each of us had to be equally activist in all pro-life activities, but to recognize that they are inseparable from one another. Can we say we are pro-life if we don't care about children living in poverty while we campaign to overturn Roe? Can we be advocating for war, supporting the death penalty, or supporting programs that gut education, food stamps or care for the mentally ill and be considered pro-life? As I understand it, the crux of his position was that they cannot be viewed as independent issues, but as all aspects of the same cloth. It is a strength that people are called to different aspects of Catholic Social Teaching, for each of them is critically important. That is the beauty of the seamless garment - the issues are integrally connected just as we are, just different colors in the tapestry.

Comment: Early in Wednesday’s hearing I testified that conversion to urban magnetic levitation (maglev) would provide a solution to rail’s problems. Other testimony suggested at-grade rail. When the legislators started questioning city officials, Rep. Andria Tupola asked about a street-level option and maglev. First, interim HART executive director Murthy stated that an at-grade system was considered and rejected as not viable because the city wanted a fully automated system. Mayor Caldwell then added that the city was committed to an elevated system. Neither of those gentlemen mentioned maglev, which would be both fully automated and elevated. The mayor has already indicated that the $8+ billion will not be enough to finish 20 miles, but it would be more than enough for maglev to not only complete the project but also extend it to meet the locally preferred alternative for alignment extensions both east and west.

Comment: You're correct, it's a difference in 𝒆𝒎𝒑𝒉𝒂𝒔𝒊𝒔 between the ledes.  The difference has no bearing on the data themselves.  Any dataset is capable of multiple non-conflicting interpretations.  

That's the situation here.  SA is focusing on the 57-39 split on the question of the 𝒂𝒑𝒑𝒓𝒐𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒂𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒆𝒔𝒔 𝒐𝒇 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝒄𝒐𝒖𝒓𝒕𝒔' 𝒓𝒖𝒍𝒊𝒏𝒈𝒔, which the 57% support.  The other website is focusing on 𝒘𝒉𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒆𝒔𝒑𝒐𝒏𝒅𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒔 𝒃𝒆𝒍𝒊𝒆𝒗𝒆 𝒊𝒔 𝑻𝒓𝒖𝒎𝒑'𝒔 𝒓𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏𝒂𝒍𝒆 𝒃𝒆𝒉𝒊𝒏𝒅 𝒉𝒊𝒔 𝑬𝑶.  No conflict at all between those questions.

Comment: The Bechdal test?  Seriously?   I couldn't help but admire this movie for its agentful female protagonist.  She demonstrates mettle and fortitude throughout the entire movie; she displays constant resistance to an infantilizing and sexually imposing predator, and, finally, the choice she makes in the final scene while listening to the radio (no spoiler, I hope).  Not to mention some serious badassary (sp?)!   There are cliches no doubt: a line or two like "You've got to be kidding me," a sophisticate and a country bumpkin bond, and when the violence gets going some impossibly close calls, but cliches are sort of requisite in thrillers.  What we didn't see in this movie, and we normally expect from this genre, is an exploitation of women and their bodies, an agentless female with, at best, a trick or two up her sleeve, or even--and holy crap!--any sex at all.  Awesome movie, which one did you watch?

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: " ...  men like Lee and Confederate president Jefferson Davis have a legacy of unadulterated evil: the fight to preserve slavery. "
.
Uh, that's an awfully broad brush.
.
Jeff Davis was a charlatan.
John C. Calhoun was a pillar of evil.
Nathan Bedford Forest was evil incarnate.
.
Robert E. Lee was commandant and senior instructor at West Point.  The majority of officers in the Union and Confederate armies were his students.  The only soldier held in higher esteem in antebellum America was Winfield Scott.  Many West Point career officers had to make choices in April 1861.  Lee, and many others, did what they thought their duty required.
.
After the war, officers from North and South attended funerals together.  
.
To lump General Lee, James Longstreet, Thomas Jackson, P.T. Beauregard, and many other professional officers in with charlatans like Jeff Davis is not an even-handed appraisal.
.
Union Army officers did not dispute that Robert E. Lee was the finest field officer of his time.

The salary of course will have benefits like an executive pension, paid leave for vacation, medical education, stress, injury, paternity etc.  My expenses like office, secretary, professional registrations/licences, transcription services, phone/internet, liability insurance, parking, etc. would be covered.  I would get overtime pay for the nights, weekends, and holidays I work (about 8-10 hours per week on top of my 60 hours normal work).  Also the salary would reflect my 17 years of education after high school.  It would also reflect that only 50 people in the country can do what I do and there are multiple offers for me to move to the USA for over 7 figures.  I'm planning to close my PC and work way less - I don't want to be greedy and save too many lives at night and on weekends and holidays.  Thanks JT - I needed a break.  Working way too hard!

Comment: "The awful question is: Why can’t we, or why won’t we, do anything about a system that presents us with two of the worst candidates in memory?"
Because collectively, we're too damn lazy to fulfill our civic responsibilities.  We don't make the time or put forth the effort to understand how our system of government works, who the candidates really are (and who is behind them), the issues of the day, our history, etc. We think by waving the flag, putting a "Support the Troops" bumper sticker on our car, and voting in November that we have fulfilled our civic duty - BULL.  We've become too self-indulgent, distracted, and preoccupied with living "the good life", and are not willing to make the sacrifices necessary to maintain a government "of, by, and for the people". The failure of our political system rests squarely on our shoulders and, as much as we point fingers and whine about whose fault it is that our country is in the shape it is, we have no one to blame but ourselves.

Comment: If an increased capital gains tax could be focused only on speculators it would be a good idea, but it can't be that selective. It is far too broad, and it would negatively affect not just speculators but also thousands of quite ordinary middle-class investors, the very people the federal government has vowed to help.  

There are lots of better tactics that do drill down to the problem itself, such as the actions that Vancouver has entertained and used: the tax on empty houses and the tax on foreign buyers. Beyond those steps, opening up new lands for housing in order to deflate demand would alleviate the crisis. But for heaven's sake don't bring on an increased capital gains tax -- it would be like using a sledge-hammer on a gnat.

Comment: The human enhanced pace of dangerous climate change is a reality and Canada has a valuable role to play in global efforts to reverse that pace.  Arguably that role is to illustrate by concrete action that a modern, advanced economy can materially reduce its carbon footprint without tanking its economic prospects.  It is the absence of proof on this point that is a major drag on global efforts to take more than token steps to address the existential threat currently posed by climate change.

Gwyn Morgan expresses the position that it vis essentially pointless for Canada to address climate change while too many of those convinced by the evidence supporting the climate change thesis are not prepared to develop sound concrete and workable models for transition to a dramatic reduction in net carbon emissions.

A well designed carbon tax regime can be an effective cornerstone for an effective middle course that would constitute the valuable Canadian contribution I describe.

Comment: Resistance of wet skin is about 1000 ohms.  Considering that resistance only (there's more added by the internals getting from through the heart via the hand making contact and the tub), if it's a 5V output charger, that means the current flowing into the body is 5V/1000 ohms, which is 0.005A...or 5 mA, which is far less than the 100 mA.  That 100mA+ that is the charging current is only a requirement of the output, and it doesn't mean that 100mA+ will flow when the charger is connected to something else.

I'm not saying there's no way it could happen, but I'm highly suspect it was only the phone charger power that killed the girl.  Now that extension cord nearby.....

In the meantime, changes in rainfall and snowfall transformed huge swathes of the American West from a fruitful terrane of lakes and meadows and streams to a semi-arid wasteland - leading to the demise of hundreds of species of iconic mammals, birds, and fish. Similarly, North Africa went from a verdant land of rivers, woods, and grasslands, populated by people and magnificent African game, to the world's largest desert.

Comment: Paranoid schizophrenia is a tough nut to crack. You can't just lock people up because they're weird. Legally, you can't medicate them if they don't want to be medicated. Some paranoid schizophrenics will never hurt anyone, except maybe themselves, while others are a risk to have out in the world. How do you know which is which before they do something harmful? Literally, you can't. I worked in the mental health field as an administrator for 15 years and that's what I learned from the social workers and psychiatrists and from watching hundreds of clients for so many years. Schizophrenics are as individual as any other humans. Some deal with their illnesses in better ways than others and some of much more capable of resisting their voices than others. They don't deserve to be punished for that. And, then there are others ....

We need to be realistic about what can and cannot be done to control people in a free society.

Comment: I recently started to work for a large corporation, fulltime, taking a hiatus from the contract lifestyle (where you don't usually have to worry about 'workplace' culture).  I don't actually care very much about most workplace culture initiatives.

What I do care about is honesty and transparency, and it's rare that any company actually acts on them.  As I just discovered the past week after 3 months at this new company  - I'd been hired in a specific role by the manager, who has since quit (her own issues with the company's 'transparency' model), and now I'm being given all kinds of slippery runarounds about the original role I accepted.  The job is okay as is, so I'll stay a while - but with this 'managing of my expectations', I've lost all trust for this company.

In addition to a decent wage and basic appreciation for work well done, I need to be able to trust my employer.  Give an employee these things, you'll have no need to agonize over workplace 'culture'.

Comment: I think in terms of church culture, it may be helpful to remember the era in which it was created. The "Western World" of the day was making the shift from a polytheistic world, towards monotheism, often adopting the Jewish model which had been around for a long time. The polytheistic model was rife with "levels," within the gods, to the civil leaders (often seen as lesser gods), to any number of social layers. There's no shortage of allusions to this in the gospels (Jesus "dared" to eat with a tax collector, or a prostitute, or touch a leper?) So I'm not surprised that there are echoes of that in the early church. What IS saddening, is that church leadership still clings to that.

Ultimately, so much of what we're seeing in our own society today is a rebellion against the echoes of that within our society (racism, sexism, elitism, etc...) Once again, society leads the church.  Jesus taught that real power wasn't in "position." A message not warmly by religious leaders, then and now.

Comment: It appears Venezuela's government is losing its ability to govern. However that state of affairs does not equate to genocide and other crimes against humanity. No such thing is happening in Venezuela, nor does it appear imminent. 

The collapse of a government can be very disorderly, even to the point of loss of life. But it's up to the people themselves to put it right and build it back up. In doing so they learn invaluable lessons, the kind that only come through hardship and loss.

Outside intervention in that process is colonial, patriarchal thinking at best. It deprives the people of an essential experience in nation-building. Canada would not be the same today had, say, the Americans interfered on the Plains of Abraham.

In nations close to collapse, any form of outside intervention risks doing more harm than good. Hands off, unless the conditions of RTP are met.

Comment: This article is a sad indictment of every adviser quoted who does not say outright that they will not roll clients out of  HC product.  How can you invest behind the HOOPP deal?

The terms are far too draconian for any firm in a short term money squeeze.  More emblematic of a firm about to enter insolvency.  Now, we do not know what other deals were offered, nor do we know all the facts about the HOOPP deal, but there are only two possible reasons it got done.

First, management at HC is poor and did not shop around, did not see the signalling of the deal and just went along with it.  (It may also be the case that the HOOPP team were too aggressive and that they tipped the boat by mistake.) This is not impossible to believe for a firm whose funding model was 84% retail without any lines of credit and other.

Second, management knows their die is cast and are just trying to slow the bleeding and provide time for an orderly wind down.

Either way, HC is not an entity that can write GICs.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... This, as we're seeing today, was a MASSIVE mistake. Gary Crum

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: openwater2010

Spousal may not work in this situation. Yes, he is in a higher tax bracket, but he contributes to a work pension and may not have any contribution room available. 

This leaves only one option left for RRSP contributions. 

Getting back to the original comment, I agree with 'begink', in their tax bracket this may not make sense.  Although I personally am a believer in RRSPs, I also understand the math involved.  If she is in a much higher tax bracket when she draws the money out (likely because it would make sense for him to 'pension split' with her) then she is better off to invest the money in a TFSA or non-registered account.  Do save the money, just do the math before putting it in a RRSP to make sure it makes sense, otherwise TFSA or non-registered account.

Comment: You're certainly entitled to vote for anyone you like. But I woldn't vote for Mr. Morneau under any circumstance.

1. Mr. Morneau's company, Morneau Shepell, currently has a multi-million dollar contract with the Bank of Canada, an entity which Mr. Morneau, as finance minister, has considerable control over. This represents a clear conflict of interest.

2. Mr. Morneau is the principal sponsor of bill C-27, which if passed into law will significantly benefit Morneau Shepell. This, too, is a clear conflict of interest.

3. Morneau knew his personal business interests should go into a blind trust, because his own correspondence confirms he asked about it when he became finance minister. Yet he ultimately chose to leverage a loophole. It's sneaky, it's deceptive, and it's greasy as hell.

Go ahead and blame Harper all you like. But Morneau's mess is Morneau's fault, and Morneau's fault alone. He tried to cheat the system and got caught. He should resign - or be fired.

Comment: Dan: Bonds are obviously conservative, low-risk investments. If you are considering replacing bonds with equities, it would make sense to use equities that are also at the low-risk, conservative end of the spectrum. At least that is what I believe and what I have done. To me the equities that come the closest to fitting that description are the most conservative pipelines and utilities where the bulk of their revenues come from regulated operations and long-term contracts with financially-sound companies. While these cash flows are not guaranteed, they come as close as any to being secure. Think companies like FTS and EMA in utilities and TRP and ENB (or ENF) in pipelines. 
These are dividend growers as opposed to the dividend payers you presented and we know that growers have historically outperformed payers. Results over your period of study
Avg ann return: +16.2%
Best yr: +35.1%
Worst yr: -15.5%
% losing periods: 14.2
Largest decline: 18.2%
Min. holding period to breakeven: <2 yrs

Comment: The following is copied directly from the IARC Q & A on their monographs: 
"What does the classification mean in terms of risk? The classification indicates the strength of the evidence that a substance or agent causes cancer. The Monographs Programme seeks to identify cancer hazards, meaning the potential for the exposure to cause cancer. However, it does not indicate the level of risk associated with exposure. The cancer risk associated with substances or agents assigned the same classification may be very different, depending on factors such as the type and extent of exposure and the strength of the effect of the agent."
IARC is limited to assessing hazard only by their own rules. Which is the basis for much of the criticism of IARC.

Comment: The vast majority of the debate about these statues ignores historical fact. Many historians that specialize in the Civil War recognize that slavery was the principle cause of the war, and it's reflected in the writings of every single secessionist state's declarations of independence. These statues were mass produced during the Jim Crow era and the Civil Rights eras in attempts to suppress progress.
The very idea of the "state's rights" argument that is so often cited by supporters of these statues is a fallacy that was perpetuated at the end of the war to promote reconciliation between the North and South during Reconstruction.
Further evidence is that General James Longstreet who post-war was pro-reconciliation and black-supporting is not represented with statues. The lack of statues for a pro-reconciliation general shows that the statues were motivated by political goals, not historic preservation.

Comment: Union picket lines? Is there a major strike going on somewhere? Where? Has the company tried to break the strike by bringing in immigrant workers? This is something that has happened about a million times in the past; is it happening now?

The way that unions traditionally deal with an economy with a labor shortage--such as we have now with unemployment under 5%--is by bargaining for higher wages and a greater share of the profits, which would make sense now because wages have essentially been flat for 30+ years despite rising productivity and growth in upper class wealth.

Conservatives, however, have had terrific success busting unions. Unions organize everyone, immigrant and native born alike and union wages would do away with the incentive to hire illegal immigrants, who get the lowest wage of all. The GOP leadership want to APPEAR to cater to blue collar anger at illegal immigrants, but, in the end, they will listen to Wall Street, the CEO's and their donors, who love low wages.

Comment: Feb 29th 1504 was a good day for Christopher Columbus too. For several months the famous explorer had been marooned on the island of Jamaica. He had been greeted warmly by the natives who helped him and his vast ship and crew survive in the foreign land by providing food and guides etc. However his arrogance and disrespect for the people had caused them to stop this gesture of goodwill. Cause, you know, he was being a dick.

Outraged by this, Columbus consulted his shipboard almanac to ask if there was anything he could use to trick the natives. As it happens, there was a lunar eclipse coming up. On the 29th feb, the day of the eclipse, he gathered the natives and told them that god was angry for their disrespect and would take away the sun. Disappearing inside his ship during the eclipse, he waited as the good people begged for their women and children. He agreed to 'bring the sun back', and essentially enslaved the people until he was rescued.

WHAT A DICK.

Comment: If I'm not mistaken, the Episcopal Church changed its name (if not its legal title) at the same time it ratified a new Book of Common Prayer in 1979. That prayer book emphasized the primacy of the Holy Eucharist in a way previous prayer books had not. The Episcopal Church "evolved," to use a popular term - it became more itself - it became more catholic (small "c") not only in terms of its liturgical practice but also in its theology. It did this in large part from having observed Vatican II from afar and absorbing the immense liturgical scholarship that emanated from it. Anglicans are smart - they've never had a problem borrowing the best of our tradition from us. It's time we return the favor and ordain some women.

Comment: "OK show me any road on Whidbey that has three or more traffic lanes???" Very well; in addition to the one I referenced above, there's also Oak Harbor Street between Crosby and Whidbey, much of Whidbey Ave west of Midway, all of Midway, much of Barrington, and multiple parts of HWY20.
You might be thinking that some of those don't count, but you'd be wrong. The WSP defines "three or more traffic lanes" to include roads with a center turning lane and two opposing traffic lanes, which would describe many road sections on Whidbey, including the one I was referring to above (see WSP PSA: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=moK9MZVSIQY, starting at 2:36). By stopping in this situation, you're unnecessarily impeding traffic. 
Be a safe driver AND know the law.

Comment: I know how you & Karan feel.  I was a homeless kid.  People weren't jumping up &  down to hire a 16yr old kid whose in high school 2hrs a day. 

When I lost my mobility & ended up in a wheel chair at 21yr all the jobs I knew how to do went out the window.  You sleep on couches, in tents, outside all the while trying to get a job & save enough money just to have a place & not even your own place but a roommate situation to boot.  We'd often get robbed staying in shelters like covenant house.  So it was safer to sleep in a park.  (If I slept at all) 

It took me 18months to get back on my feet.  I struggled paycheck to paycheck so that I could go to college & keep a roof, If anything would have happened to my job I would of ended up right back on the street.  It took me another 5yrs of savings to get myself in a better financial situation.  

That was over 12years ago but it sure humbles you for life.  I've taken in homeless teens 16-19yr.  I've paid for parents to keep their lights on..

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: The Iditarod should end. This treacherous, unnecessary race is exploitative and cruel to the dogs in many ways. It kills dogs just about every year; the total known is 146. Dog deaths average about two per race. They are raced beyond their limits. Six dogs died in 2009. Two dogs (Stiffy and Wyatt, both only three years old) died on "champion" Mackey's team one year. Many dogs do not finish the race every year. The dogs are dropped due to injury, illness, exhaustion, or not wanting to continue. Mushers finish with only half (or less) of the 16, and some finish with only 5 dogs.

These dogs are chained (considered inhumane and illegal in many communities) their entire lives to their small, dilapidated enclosures, unable to play or interact with their kennel mates, unless they are training,—all at the behest of their mushers. They are treated as slaves at the ready to perform.

Comment: Roads are only a piece of total driving cost.  Drivers pay for their vehicles, their maintenance, their insurance, their fuel, etc.  That can easily add up to a long-term average of $4000/yr or more.  Road costs add onto that.

Conversely, transit includes the cost of everything rolled into one: the vehicles, maintenance, insurance, fuel, and the tracks/stations.

The share of total driving cost that the actual user pays is likely around 80% (since most of it goes to vehicle/fuel/etc that they pay 100% for).  Conversely, transit riders only pay 30% of their own way.

Comment: Karyn,

While I share your disgust at the lynch-mob mentality that exists in the age of social media,  your concern that engaging the points raised by the author would subvert the debate on equality seems to be based more on the fact that you hold an opposing view to him than it is on the actual events. 

To debate is to exchange opposing views. To suggest that we ignore this author's view and what happened, as it may subvert the debate, is a non sequitur. 

In my view, the fact that we allow ourselves to intellectualise hate speech if it emanates from one demographic but recognise it as such if it comes from another, is valid cause for concern and worthy of engagement.  Not recognising a point because of who made it will do more to subvert honest debate around social inequality and white privilege than engaging with it will.

Comment: Since I believe that human life begins at conception, how can I "concede"---what right do I have to "concede"---anything that would be a death warrant for certain human beings? 

What I CAN concede, and many times have, is that reasonable people of good faith can disagree about whether a person worthy of protection exists from conception onward.  This is where Roe v. Wade went off the tracks. I hate to concede it, but I must: New York, California, Ohio, whatever---all have the right to say that abortion is always just fine! As an American, I accept that that's the democratic process. By the same token, it can go the other way, too---and the Roe Court had to turn legal pretzels (and do lasting damage to constitutional law far beyond the scope of abortion) in order to reach the conclusion it did. On this point, read a classic, "The Wages of Crying Wolf," by Jon Hart Ely, who personally supported the right to abortion.  It's worthy of a Pulitzer. May God inspire your search for the truth.

Comment: The amount of the deficit and the total national debt, per se, are not really the problem.  The debt will never, ever be repaid anyway.  it's the MoneyMart-style compound interest treadmill that we're on that's leeching us in perpetuity.

When we run a budget deficit, one of the expenses included in the budget is the amount of interest we are required to pay on previously borrowed money.  Since we have to borrow even more to cover the budget shortfall, we are in effect borrowing money to pay the interest on the previous debt.  Simple arithmetic shows that must inevitably end in collapse.  Except for one faint hope thing that is dangled before us.

If the economy can be made to grow at a rate faster than the growth of the interest bill as a percentage of the budget, then theoretically the financial "tomorrow" never has to come.  Thus Trudeau's comment that the budget will balance itself if the economy grows sufficiently.

It sounds plausible but it's actually fiscal Three Card Monte.

Comment: If the City didn't need to borrow money for the project -- i.e. if revenues kept up with costs all the way through -- there would only be construction costs and no financing costs.  In that case the project cost would be about $8.2 billion. The City has cited this figure pretty consistently during the session.

However there ARE financing costs, which VARY depending on the revenue source. The excise tax surcharge produces steady, slow-growing revenue that falls short of construction costs during much of the construction period, but continues on after construction ends. So paying for rail with the excise tax surcharge requires lots of short-term borrowing, which adds interest expense, which bumps up the total project cost to around $10 billion. A hotel room tax increase could generate more revenue faster, decreasing borrowing and lowering interest expense.

The legislature's indecision on a revenue source is what's moving the numbers around, yet Saiki blames the City.  Ah, politics.

Comment: I'm not anti oil. I'm just opposed to bitter, sore losers, that spout off baselessly claiming that the system is rigged to help some producers. The system is set up to maximize safe production of resources to maximize Alaska's profit. The only reason one would think the system is unfair or incapable of being satisfied is if you are type of business that seeks to profit by skirting the rules, or cannot afford to follow them. Comment: In the '80s we started using 'air-tight' wood stoves that basically damped down the incoming air to a hot fire, so it would smolder all night long.  That produced lots of unburned elements, that also gummed up the chimney.  Once per day you should 'let it go' to burn off that residue, was the mantra.
From all this I conclude that a hot fire is a clean fire.  Most wood stoves are too big to run wide open all the time, and they'd also sublimate faster, the walls should be as thick as possible.
In the USA, I built a house with a masonry, air-tight wood stove, by simply adding airtight doors to the firebox, of a normal, 35' high chimney.  The firebox was surrounded with 30 or 40 tons of thermal mass.  That allows you to only burn the appliance at it's hottest setting, for as long as it takes to warm up the masonry, which then keeps the house warm, until the next day.  (Week in the case of the Alabama house, it was also constructed of 180 tons of blocks and concrete, inside the conditioned

Comment: The fight is not always about survival, but rather about the fight to die with dignity and to make the most of your final days. Those facing life threatening diseases like cancer all deal with their illnesses differently, as their illnesses are as unique as they are. My father-in-law was diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer, he initially sought a second opinion regarding treatment, when the second doctor concurred with the first, he chose go on hospice and return to his home town to spend his remaining days with his loved ones with as much comfort and dignity as possible. He received medals in the Korean War and will always be our hero. Our most basic instinct is fight or flight, I was diagnosed with an aggressive breast cancer 6 years ago. I am currently in remission, I worked through chemo and radiation and drew strength from my coworkers, my struggle was to keep life as normal as possible and I found happiness in little things. I will continue to fight like a girl.

$2500.00 individual contribution plus $2500 employer contribution for $5000 yearly max going into your fund.

Comment: So sick of the alternative facts. We have more than enough STEM grads.  For example, read the 2015 report on underemployment among engineering graduates from the Ontario Society of Professional Engineers.   It shows that about 1/3 of engineering graduates are working in jobs which do not require a university education of any kind.    There is a huge glut of engineering labour, yet the government approves every application the universities make to expand enrolment.

What employers are saying when they complain about a shortage of engineers, is that they can't find people off the street who have five years' experience in some particular niche of engineering, who are willing to work for what they want to pay.  The solution surely lies in the direction of hiring new grads and training them, and not leaving Canadian grads to sell fishing rods at Canadian Tire.

Comment: I think it's a travesty that a person of color gets extra points over a white kid with the same test scores. It's a mockery of integration. It says "if you're white, you're not wanted, you are less-than." How is that any different than when we treated people of color in a similar fashion? It's not. It's still discrimination justified by bigotry only instead of saying the reason is skin color we now say we're correcting "white privilege" A kid who was born in the last 20 years shouldn't be held responsible for conditions in past generations. That's an excuse that we ought to stop using in this country. We will be a truly post-racial society when the color of someone skin doesn't matter at all and two people with the same test scores will have an equal chance of being selected based on some other character-based criteria beyond their test scores. I'm speaking as someone who is mixed race (American Indian) and I don't want my children treated as "special". Affirmative action needs to go.

Comment: That would be a huge tax increase, and probably throw the economy into recession.

I agree that the debt is way too high and soaring ever higher.  We're overspending as a federal government.  Generating more tax revenues is fine, as long as it's done the right way -- by growing the economy and broadening the base.  That means lower base rates but fewer (ideally NO) deductions/breaks/credits.  

Personally I's shrink corporate income taxation significantly (that just passes through to consumers anyway in the form of higher prices, and makes US business less competitive), lower individual income taxation modestly, and add a national sales tax of 3-5%.  Sales taxes are one of the best ways to make sure everyone pays a fair share, and it's far harder to "tax break" your way out of it.  It's paid a tiny bit at a time throughout the year rather than in one big chuck.  As such, most people won't bother trying to get out of it and just pay it.

Comment: Probably because the store is very careful to follow the laws, but the interpretation of those laws changes from year to year and from agency head to agency head. What was acceptable last year is suddenly illegal this year and those who deal in these artifacts have no way of predicting how the law will be enforced next year. Ten years ago, if an ivory carving was purchased in a collection it was considered legal. Apparently now, the agency wants to force antique dealers to PROVE that the piece was, in fact, produced by a native artist even though many beautiful pieces predate the Marine Mammal Protection act by decades and proof is virtually impossible. The critters from which the articles were made are long dead. If there was illegal profit from their deaths it was made by somebody generations ago. The purpose appears to be driving up the price for current carvers who buy tusks and horns from natives who slaughter critters strictly for the ivory.

Comment: I think that, as a consumer who values competition in the marketplace, we should stick with supporting the system of shipping methods that all retailers in the economy may use. Vertical and horizontal corporate trusts should be broken up by the FTC on principle for the sake of US consumer protection and liberty from corporate predilection and predation. Beyond that, in this age of National Security Letters and high-profile hacking exfiltrations of consumer privacy from corporate enterprises great and small alike, trust is in very short supply.

To whom you grant access to your locked home or control over that lock electronically should be scrutinized with all due diligence with high standards and in a pure fashion, because this sort of security seems to me an absolute all-or-nothing affair. I'm pretty sure that Amazon is functionally opaque to sufficient such diligence. The last thing you need is to discover a system like this being used against your own best enlightened interests.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: I know that acts of kindness can be layered with motives and some of these motives can involve ego. Nonetheless, I still believe, even when the motives are not 100% pure, there is value to giving. 

About 5 years ago, I had the opportunity to help a stranger, who had a stroke. A year or so later, while lunching with a friend, I shared what I had done. He asked why I did it. I replied "it made me feel good to have helped". He angrily shot back "your selfish". I asked him what he meant. He then said "you did it because it made you feel good". I replied, with more than a hint of sarcasm, "well, I think compassion was somewhere in the mix".

So, I have accepted that, even, the best of who I am can be infiltrated with other motives. I don't ever expect to achieve perfection in this life and, certainly, not perfection in my giving. Still, , I won't discount the value of giving because it makes one feel good. 

John David

Comment: Finally a decision that makes sense. As for all the hatchery critics out there, understand that I don't disagree with some of the negative consequences that have come out of hatcheries in the past. They continued to do things the same way as they always did, despite habitat and harvest impacts to wild fish. But you also have to look at the other side of the coin, up until the HSRG review, very few hatcheries made any attempt at removing excess hatchery fish, and continued to use broodstock that wasn't locally adapted. This caused immeasurable genetic changes to the wild spawning population. We can't go back and change what has happened, we can only do better, and try to limit the effects of hatchery impacts to wild stocks. That being said, in the case of the Elwa, there really isn't a wild stock to mine eggs or broodstock from, at least not in numbers that are sustainable. using the hatchery, as a tool, for rebuilding a locally adapted broodstock is the only answer.

Comment: People, these days, don't seem to have enough time to actually think through a situation and understand all sides to it. Back in the day when I was going to school, that was called critical thinking - and it took time and guidance - stuff we seem to have very little supply of these days. Critical thinking is discounted because it "muddies up the water" and de-fangs points of view that, if just laid out without a counter, are more binary than they are thought out concepts. Binary points of view are easier to digest, and in some cases more profitable than to actually be critically thinking on all sides. 
As pointed out to me in school whenever I would get into trouble with someone - there is two sides to everything and it takes the judicious to rationalize both sides. Because in that examination, the core issue comes to light and then, only then, can you really start discussing and finding solutions.  That creates wisdom, and unfortunately wisdom is both scarce and not very profitable.

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: "Today, Canadians, for example, can own their own homes and buy land thanks to treaties that the government negotiated," the draft version says. "Every Canadian has responsibilities under those treaties as well. They are agreements of honour."

This is not really accurate. No particular aboriginal land rights were ever proven in any particular area befor the Numbered Treaties were entered into. It was assumed that the pre-treaty inhabitants of the area would have some land rights at various locations within the Treaty area, but not the entire area.  Rather than have the situation that currently exists in (mostly) non-Treaty BC,  where aboriginal land rights have to be claimed and proven (if not settled beforehand), the Treaties effected a complete surrender of any and all potential land claims within their area (and even beyond). So, no, not every home would have needed to be covered by a Treaty in order to be free of any aborignal  treaty claim, as the guide implies.

Comment: Driver's licenses is a great example of how this bill fails rehabilitation.  Currently the punishment for driving with a revoked license includes jail time - UNLESS you go and get your license.  If you can get a license you are given an opportunity to get one (and all the insurance) in order to avoid jail. 

That's what rehabilitation in the criminal justice system looks like.  Take someone and force them to jump through the hoops they won't on their own (go to the DMV, complete the paperwork, pay the fines, get insurance).  

This bill will just remove the incentive entirely.  It pretends to want to get people on track - but offers no path to do that.

Comment: 20 years ago, when faced with the prospect of ever declining North Slope oil production, ARCO Alaska undertook a radical reorganization.  Major reductions were made in many departments, among them the Major Projects organization and Government and Public Affairs.  Layers of middle management disappeared. Total headcount went from about 2500 to about 1700.  Hundreds of jobs were re-graded.  No one took a pay cut.  But salaries were frozen until performance and years of service moved an employee up within their new, lower grade.  All of this was announced and implemented in a matter of a few months.  People weren't happy.  Some left the company because the career advancements achieved so far disappeared.  They found jobs elsewhere.  But most stayed.  And a year later, the new organization was functioning well and people had adjusted to a new reality.  Most were content to still be in Alaska doing jobs they loved.  U of A should consider this approach.

Comment: There are some aspects that deserve further examination. 

"labyrinthine payments system involving countless insurers". However that applies to all insurance services, fire, auto, house.. and does not appear to result in high cost. Competition reduces cost.

Further a single payer system is a monopoly and that usually results in high cost.

Medicare (for seniors and the disabled) means that people who are perfectly capable of paying their own way, are paid for by the taxpayer. Since Medicaid covers the poor, there is no need for Medicare. 

The private sector provides virtually all the needs and wants of Americans very satisfactorily, except health care.There the connection between poor Americans and the medical system is broken. I would suspect that the poor outcomes of the US system is due to the poor not getting help and when they get sick the cost is very high. 

Certainly Americans will be hit on occasion by high medical cost, the same as some people will be hit by accidents.

Comment: This story might be good clickbait (which pays the bills for online media) but it’s irresponsible journalism. The writer is clearly trying to bracket the proprietors of Saffron Colonial with the actual racists of American Renaissance. Of course there's no connection between the two. That's a smear.

Regarding the actual subject matter:

In order to engage with each other profitably, we need to assume the best intentions in others, and to re-learn the virtues of tolerance. In this particular case, some historical realism might help too. Colonialism was bad, fine, but it was also a fact. And the blending of cultures under colonialism also gave us some great good. Without colonialism, for example, there would be no modern Mexican cuisine (Native American + Spanish) or banh mi (Vietnamese + French), or tikka masala (Indian + British).  Who wants to live in a world like that?

Comment: This author has no idea what she is talking about.  The 2nd Amendment was written into the Constitution as a right that pre-existed the formation of the 13 colonies and the United States.   The founding fathers not only authorized the "individual's" right to bear arms but that the "individual" had the right to protect him or herself against not only other citizens but also against an oppressive government.  And it authorized the "individual" to possess the same firearms as soldiers and the militia.   For the record, the US Supreme Court held in 1876 that the 2nd Amendment did not refer only to a "well regulated militia" but also to  individual citizens.  See United States v. Cruikshank, 92 U.S. 542, (1876).  See also Presser v. Illinois, 116 U.S. 252 (1886).   At the time of both of these Supreme Court interpretations we had a US Army, US Navy, US Marines, and the US Coast Guard.   Incidentally, the Bill of Rights was passed over 15 years after we had all of the above armed forces.

Comment: Trump himself tweets links to news stories based on leaks.
I have conflicted opinions about leaks.
Any president, Trump included, needs to be able to talk to foreign leaders on a confidential basis without someone within the White House leaking the call. Presidents need to have give and take with foreign leaders. All presidents have a learning curve in the first year. Look how Republicans mocked Obama for not knowing whether to bow or shake hands with a foreign leader (Japan's emperor? the Saudi king?). Same with some of Trump's confidential conversations.
Everyone with a need to know already was learning North Korea has allegedly figured out how to miniaturize a nuclear weapon, including the Russian, Chinese, and other countries' intelligence agencies as well.
But, OTOH, when intelligence agencies leak, that's a concern. Who leaked? For what purpose? It adds a random selective dimension to what the public is being told, and is driven by someone's personal agenda to skew debate.

Buying more food in bulk a key. Hummingbird has a huge food list that can be bought in bulk, almost all organic. Also Growers Market at 454 Willamette a good source for reasonable food prices. Many food stores have bulk foods.

Pizza boxes: I wash, dry and use it repeatedly. Have done this for years, have not seen anyone else do it.

Comment: It was not a solid company, obviously.  It lent into one sector only, to very risky clients.  The only reason the whole subprime industry has done fairly well in Canada, until this, is that between foreign buyers, and enough solid-income Canadian buyers, the shaky borrowers could sell in a pinch.  Then nobody ever heard about how close to the edge they were in the sense of not covering payments from labour income, or the rent generated by an extra property.  Hopefully political outrage will drive Junior to limit the foreign buyers in a few ways, and cut the domestic side of the bubble by scaling back CMHC's involvement.  
Finally, will the Globe maybe tie together their two story lines?  We hear of Home Capital, supposedly a black swan, actually predictable as hell, then in other stories we have heard of all the investors burned in small-to-medium real-estate securitization schemes.  Really all one industry, with fraud ranging from "fibbing a bit about risk" to "outright Ponzi."

Comment: Arlington was selected as the site for aesthetic and practical reasons, and the fact that it would have prevented Robert E. Lee from ever returning to his home again was certainly a consideration.  In 1884, long after Lee's death, the U.S. Supreme Court in The United States v. Lee gave the Lee family a moral victory by deciding the property had been confiscated without due process.  However, by then its purpose as a national cemetery was a fait accompli, so it was sold back to the government less than a year later.

Much of North-South animosity has faded in the century-and-a-half since Robert E. Lee's front yard became a cemetery.  But I think Arlington remains a favored visitor destination because of its natural beauty and tranquility.  For those reasons too, it is inarguably a most appropriate final resting place for anyone who served his country well.

Comment: B G,

Unless and until Canada's immigration policies and the immigrants we select to settle here pose a danger to the US, it is really not their business what our choices in that regard are or may become.  I'm sure that the US would not welcome input from Canada on their corresponding issues and Canada doesn't enjoy a subordinate relationship with the US whereby we need to ape every twist and turn of changes in their policies.

By the same token, we should not avoid following policies that we independently deem appropriate for Canada simply because the US chooses to follow a similar course.

The best course is for Canada to continue to act in a calm, mature manner to follow its own carefully considered interests and values in the matter of immigration.  In all likelihood, the US will have too many other domestic and foreign issues to address to gratuitously become involved in a spat over this issue with Canada.  If, however, they pressure us, we need to stand firm in a mature fashion.

Comment: From the late 1930s until June 14, 1941, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt (FDR) issued an Executive Order freezing German assets, Chase National Bank worked with the Nazi government. The order blocking any access to French accounts in the U.S. by anyone, but especially by the Nazis was issued by Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr., with the approval of FDR. Within hours of the order, Chase unblocked the accounts and the funds were transferred through South America to Nazi Germany.

Um, no.

Not standard fare at all.

Americans rarely talk about Canada. 

The thing is, when they do, the Canadian media dutifully amplifies the (rare) event by ten thousand, with TV repeats and opinion columns.

A decade or two back, a (nobody) political commentator in the US called Canada "Soviet Canuckistan".

It was a throw-away line that made no impact on Americans, less than two percent even watch the show he was on.

But in Canada, our media reported it as if George W. Bush had just invaded every Canadian city with a thousand US army tanks.

Drop your illusion. Americans do not think about Canada, they do not care about Canada. You make the grave mistake of assuming that the USA is like a mirror image of Canada, in how often Canadians talk about America.

It is not.

Comment: "Democrats, they note, pushed for expansion of health-insurance subsidies for low- and middle-income Americans; investments in education and retraining; middle-class tax cuts; and a higher minimum wage."

The Affordable Care Act has helped some people but it has a lot of problems that came with the design. Many people can't afford the premiums and deductibles, even with subsidies, plus they don't like being forced to buy a product that doesn't really meet their needs.  We need single-payer health insurance.

Federal investments in education and retraining have not been enough to meet the needs of working-class people, who really need jobs that pay a living wage. Middle-class tax cuts obviously don't help working-class people, and they force cutbacks in government services we depend on. The federal minimum wage is still only $7.25 per hour. Trade deals have cost us jobs. We are not grateful. 

Democrats are avoiding reality. They can give us what we need or keep losing elections.

Thank you for sharing your concerns. I've had a look at your account, and to be quite honest I'm not sure of the reason for your restriction! In your case, it looks like a moderator at ADN chose to restrict your account, possibly because of the most recent comment you've had deleted, "Shit for brains is too kind."

Thanks,
Emily

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: In a totalitarian system, the government knows everything about its citizens. In particular it knows who you are and where you are at all times. Anonymity is eliminated with extreme prejudice, because a threat to the system could lie behind the veil.

Comment: Bad idea. Let's focus on BHP.  First, we don't know when Paul Singer bought the stock, but  it spiked about $1.50 on the open the day of his letter.

So, before any transaction costs the first 5% move in the stock in over before this article hits the press.  how big a win is expected is unknown, but in a world of tight risk premia any bet this late is too late.

But, this is not the only issue.  BHP is an Australian stock with a beta to that market, a beta to iron ore and metal prices and therefore to world GDP.  We do not know how Singer is sizing up those risks and hedging them with other metals stock, Australian stocks or commodity futures. 

Finally, we won't know if and when he exits based on success or failure of his activist effort. Nor will we see his correspondence or hear any calls with management. Activists often drag others into their deals, but rarely share their insights so they can be the fist to cut losses.  If you buy BHP you help Singer win, but maybe not yourself.

Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: I wasn't attempting to disparage how you read.  Apologies if you interpret my comments that way.

Well, despite your protests, I have cited a nation that kept distributions of wealth and incomes at a healthy level -- the US from the end of WWII to the mid 1980's.  During those decades, the Gini index was in the high 30's which would put us in the neighborhood of modern Japan, but not as equitable as the Scandinavian countries, many of which are in the 20's.  See: https://www.chartbookofeconomicinequality.com/inequality-by-country/usa/

UBI, which might or might not be the best way to lower income inequality, would bring the Gini index down a bit, especially if it was funded by raising the top bracket income tax rate, or by eliminating tax loopholes used by wealthy families.  

Near the middle of the period I'm talking about, in 1960 during the Republican Eisenhower administration, the top bracket income tax rate was around 90%

Comment: Then you're aware that the capacitance of the line, and hence the charging current, are a function of the line geometry as well as voltage, but a higher voltage means lower current , therefore lower losses and greater capacity and efficiency.  The single line from Dave's Cr to Anchorage is stability limited to 75 MW, therefore it's unlikely that that line can support both Bradley and a new plant at Snow River.  So the cost of the plant will need about $150 - $$200M, kaching!!, for an additional line and substation because it's unlikely the existing one can be reconductored to 230 kV. Snow River hydro is not going to be built anytime soon, if ever, because although the rated capacity is 75 MW, the capacity factor is going to be maybe 45%, so it's hard to envision financing a $750M+  project that wouldn't even supply half the average load on the Kenai Peninsula.  Dusting this project off and tossing it into the public arena smells like political maneuvering to achieve other ends.

Comment: Fairbanks Daily News-Miner has six staff writers. I guess they may have 25-50 support staff - production, ad people, circulation, office staff,  etc. It's has a circulation of 9,000-9,500 daily and 12,500 on Sundays, and by all indications, they hare financially solvent.

So, ADN had definitely been high on staffing levels. I suspect the Dispatch wasn't making a good profit margin before it bought the Anchorage Daily News. Rogoff thought she could creatively finance and use the power of the print company to stay afloat, but her political propaganda caused  a loss of readership which affected her bottom line. A newspaper can't function as a hobby. Few businesses can.

The good news is that the Binkleys have a long history of being competitive business people, so if they can fix the structural problems that Rogoff created, they should be able to turn it around. But I doubt everyone will keep their jobs.

Comment: As a member of the Board of Directors for the Tanaina Child Development Center, I can assure you that the Center never made "massive amounts of money" while being housed at UAA. Each year expenditures were within 1 or 2% of revenues, some years the Center lost money.  There was no real savings account.

And since I was involved, I will tell you that the Child Development Center was not kicked out to make space for the Locker Room remodel, but because the space needed to be vacated for 6 months due to the construction, the Administration found it to be a "convenient" time to remove the center permanently (and is now occupied by Student Affairs).

Points are not free, they are funded by consumers who participate in the program through arrangements with vendors that build the cost into their prices. Airmiles are attempting to take advantage of a situation in which they hold all the cards at the expense of points holders who were expecting to be treated fairly.

Comment: “Like any other group or any other division in the police department you need the supervision to be very, very tight to make sure that they’re doing what they’re supposed to do,” Okimoto said. “When you don’t have that and you don’t have those controls in place then things like this could happen real easily.”  

"The most important quality in a CIU officer is trust, [Perry] said."  “I think that loyalty went just a little bit too far in this situation and they didn’t know how to stop. It’s a tough one. You have to say no.”

 A "little bit too far," could be a slight understatement.  

“Sometimes you have to say this is wrong, I’m taking the high road and I’m not going to follow those orders even if you transfer or suspend me,” Perry said. “And it takes a brave person to do that, especially in an organization like the Honolulu Police Department.” 

Only "sometimes"?  No wonder "some" have referred to Hawaii as one of the most corrupt states.  But, only "sometimes."
